text: Question for any technical SEOs here: We're building a library of educational content on our site. Is there any downside to making the majority of the content PDFs instead of web pages? All our content is in presentation slides format.

elements.text: Question for any technical SEOs here: We're building a library of educational content on our site. Is there any downside to making the majority of the content PDFs instead of web pages? All our content is in presentation slides format.

text: Yes, this is a huge difference. Google can read the text on a web page and use that to understand what the text is about and what queries are relevant. PDFs are a huge no-go for that — this is a big enough difference that if I were leading a project internally I would absolutely stop everything until we could get content up as web pages

elements.text: Yes, this is a huge difference. Google can read the text on a web page and use that to understand what the text is about and what queries are relevant. PDFs are a huge no-go for that — this is a big enough difference that if I were leading a project internally I would absolutely stop everything until we could get content up as web pages

text: Also, not a great experience for anyone reading on mobile.

elements.text: Also, not a great experience for anyone reading on mobile.

text:
<@UJ7RT1J1X> I found some articles like this one saying that Google indexes PDFs just like other web content: <https://www.thesearchreview.com/google-we-index-pdfs-just-like-any-other-web-page-29318/#:~:text=PDFs%20are%20just%20one%20of,PowerPoint%2C%20and%20various%20programming%20languages>.

The exact concern you raised is the one that prompted my question here, but then I've read a few articles like that one I linked :point_up: that are contradictory. Honestly just super confused at this point haha. Thoughts?

attachments.title: Does Google index PDF files and content?
attachments.text: John Mueller, Webmaster Trends Analyst at Google, confirmed that they index PDF files and content in the Google Search just like they would any other webpage.
attachments.fallback: Does Google index PDF files and content?

elements.text: I found some articles like this one saying that Google indexes PDFs just like other web content:

.

The exact concern you raised is the one that prompted my question here, but then I've read a few articles like that one I linked
that are contradictory. Honestly just super confused at this point haha. Thoughts?

text: Thanks <@U0166H7KUAZ>, agreed. We wrote some custom code to make the PDFs show up nicely on mobile :nerd_face:

elements.text: Thanks
, agreed. We wrote some custom code to make the PDFs show up nicely on mobile

text: Google has definitely improved, but I would definitely also not say that there's parity between PDFs and web pages

elements.text: Google has definitely improved, but I would definitely also not say that there's parity between PDFs and web pages

text: ^ also much harder to track the analytics of a PDF

elements.text: ^ also much harder to track the analytics of a PDF

text: Very true on the analytics piece.

elements.text: Very true on the analytics piece.

text: And ugh I know. My gut agrees with you. It would just be a *huge* amount of work for us to convert from PDF to web-page. I guess I secretly had my heart set on PDFs. We also know our users strongly prefer the PDF presentation format for our content so there's that as well.

elements.text: And ugh I know. My gut agrees with you. It would just be a
huge

amount of work for us to convert from PDF to web-page. I guess I secretly had my heart set on PDFs. We also know our users strongly prefer the PDF presentation format for our content so there's that as well.

text: The other issue with PDFs is accessibility. The UK government has actually passed legislation requiring public bodies to not use PDFs for this reason (though I understand there is such a thing as an accessible PDF).

elements.text: The other issue with PDFs is accessibility. The UK government has actually passed legislation requiring public bodies to not use PDFs for this reason (though I understand there is such a thing as an accessible PDF).
